author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Plan to Fast-Track Voting Rights Bill, Speeding a Showdown
description: The move will allow for debate on the legislation to begin this week, hastening a confrontation with Republicans and the moment when Democrats could try to change Senate rules.
content: WASHINGTON — Moving quickly to force a showdown over voting rights, congressional Democrats plan to pursue a procedural shortcut to bring up stalled legislation and try to win its approval over deep Republican resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Trump Ends NPR Interview After Challenges to False Fraud Claim
description: Former President Donald J. Trump abruptly ended the interview after a lengthy back-and-forth over his claims of widespread election fraud.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump abruptly ended an interview with NPR on Tuesday after he was pressed on his false claim of a stolen election in 2020 and how he was using that assertion to put pressure on Republicans before the 2022 midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: The Reason Every N.F.L. Playoff Team Will Lose
description: Only one of these teams will prove us wrong.
content: There are no nigh-unbeatable 1972 Miami Dolphins or 2007 New England Patriots in this year’s N.F.L. playoff field. Each team has at least one critical flaw. Opposing coaches have spent countless hours scouring game film and statistical breakdowns searching for those flaws. All you have to do is read the following capsules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Evan Smith, the leader of The Texas Tribune, says he will step down.
description: After 13 years at the helm, he says goodbye to the nonprofit news organization he helped start.
content: Evan Smith, a longtime force in Texas journalism, said on Wednesday that he would step down as the chief executive of The Texas Tribune, the nonprofit news organization he has led for 13 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Trip Gabriel
title: David McCormick, Hedge Fund Chief, Joins Pennsylvania G.O.P. Senate Fray
description: A former Treasury official, Mr. McCormick has drawn comparisons to Glenn Youngkin, the financier recently elected governor of Virginia.
content: David McCormick, the former chief executive of Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund, filed paperwork to run for the Senate in Pennsylvania as a Republican on Wednesday, entering a crowded but unsettled field in what is likely to be one of the most hotly contested midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Debates Catching Omicron on Purpose
description: “I mean, all the other late-night hosts are doing it,” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Biden Administration Approves 5 More Guantánamo Releases
description: Nearly half of the last 39 detainees have now been approved for transfer, and the challenge for U.S. officials is to find countries to receive them.
content: WASHINGTON — A U.S. government review panel has approved the release of five men who have been held for years without charge at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, according to a flurry of decisions released by the Pentagon on Tuesday, but they are unlikely to be freed soon as the Biden administration works to find nations to take them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Car Bomb Kills 8 in Somalia’s Capital
description: The explosion, one of a string of recent attacks, comes as the country grapples with a political standoff and a growing humanitarian crisis.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A large explosion killed at least eight people and injured nine others in Mogadishu on Wednesday, according to the head of an ambulance service, the latest attack to hit Somalia’s capital as the country grapples with political infighting and a growing humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Rotunno
title: Burn These After Reading
description: With the pandemic prompting home improvements large and small, many have looked to the past for décor, setting the stage — or table — for a candle and candlestick resurgence.
content: Between 400,000 and one million years ago, our ancestors made fire. This one creation changed the course of daily life, and it would take yet another few hundred thousand more years, according to the National Candle Association in Washington, D.C., for candles to appear. Candles and candlesticks have since become fixtures of religious observances, a decorative note in homes and restaurants, and lighting them up has turned into a soothing personal ritual for many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Democrats are working to kill a Republican measure to slap sanctions on the Nord Stream 2 pipeline.
description: The Democrats’ bill would impose new sanctions on Russian officials if Moscow invaded Ukraine.
content: Senate Democrats unveiled legislation on Wednesday that would impose sanctions on top Russian officials if Moscow invaded Ukraine, in an effort to squash a competing Republican-led bill that would impose sanctions on a Russian natural-gas pipeline that bypasses Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Is Omicron Peaking?
description: There are very early signs that cases may have begun to plateau in some places.
content: Ever since the Omicron surge began, researchers have been trying to predict when cases might peak. Estimates generally place that event sometime during this month, but some calculations seem to have been too optimistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: How Exercise May Tame Our Anxiety
description: Cross-country ski racers were less likely to develop anxiety disorders. The good news is less intense aerobic activities may provide similar benefits.
content: To better cope with all the dispiriting news this winter about rising Covid-19 cases and so much else, you might want to get out and play in the snow, according to a new report. The large-scale study of almost 200,000 cross-country skiers found that being physically active halves the risk of developing clinical anxiety over time. The study, from Sweden, focused on skiing, but the researchers said almost any kind of aerobic activity likely helps protect us against excessive worry and dread, a cheering thought as we face yet another grim pandemic season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: “The moment to defend our democracy is now.”
content: Speaking in Atlanta yesterday, President Biden endorsed changing Senate rules and weakening the filibuster to pass new voting rights legislation, warning of a grave threat to American democracy if lawmakers did not act to “protect the heart and soul” of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: stalwart
description: This word has appeared in 173 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Djokovic Admits False Statement on Australia Travel Document
description: The tennis star also said he had participated in an interview and a photo shoot even after testing positive for the coronavirus, in an apparent violation of rules in his native Serbia.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Novak Djokovic, the top-ranked men’s tennis player, acknowledged on Wednesday that a travel document he presented to Australian border officials last week contained false information, as the country’s authorities continued to investigate whether he should be deported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Ken Belson
title: Pro Sports Leagues Are Chasing Gen Z Where It Plays
description: Here’s what sports marketers are doing to win back a lost generation and save the future of fandom.
content: The N.F.L. teamed with the gamer Ninja. Major League Baseball recruited influencers to produce TikTok content for the World Series under the hashtag #mlbcreatorclass. The N.B.A. co-founded the professional NBA 2K e-sports league and tied it to individual franchises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Can the G.O.P. Recover From the ‘Big Lie’? We Asked 2 Conservatives
description: A look at how Trump has shaped the Republican Party and where it goes next.
content: There’s a divide in the Republican Party between those who believe the “Big Lie” — that the election was stolen from President Donald Trump — and those who don’t. But which side is ultimately the future of the party?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Robins
title: What is NATO?
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a military alliance of Western powers, was created during the Cold War and remains central to Western diplomatic and military cooperation.
content: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization was the heart of the U.S.-led, anti-Soviet military alliance during the decades of the Cold War, and remains central to Western diplomatic and military cooperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Let’s Not Invent a Civil War
description: It’s possible to worry about America’s divisions without falling into perpetual alarmism.
content: “How Civil Wars Start,” a new book by the political scientist Barbara F. Walter, was cited all over the place in the days around the anniversary of last winter’s riot at the Capitol. The New Yorker’s David Remnick, Vox’s Zack Beauchamp and my colleague Michelle Goldberg all invoked Walter’s work in essays discussing the possibility that the United States stands on the edge of an abyss, with years of civil strife ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Dale Clevenger, Chicago Symphony’s Fearless Horn Master, Dies at 81
description: Mr. Clevenger, who played his notoriously treacherous instrument with daring, was an anchor of the Chicago orchestra’s famed brass section for 47 years.
content: Dale Clevenger, whose expressive, daring playing as the solo French horn of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for 47 years made him one of the most respected orchestral instrumentalists of his generation, died on Jan. 5 at a hospital near his home in Brescia, Italy. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $425,000 Homes in Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania
description: A Gothic Revival house in Indianapolis, a Tudor Revival home in Cincinnati and a 1912 rowhouse in Pittsburgh.
content: Fletcher Place Historic District, one of Indiana’s oldest urban neighborhoods, was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982. This house is just outside the boundaries of the official historic district, where streets are lined with Italianate, Queen Anne and Gothic Revival homes built in the 1870s and 1880s. Nearby Virginia Avenue is a nightlife destination, with gastro pubs, an arcade-themed bar and a craft spirits distillery. The corporate offices and laboratories of Eli Lilly and Company are a five-minute drive; downtown Indianapolis is 10 minutes away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden’s Longtime Defense of Senate Rules Withers Under Partisan Rancor
description: The president left no doubt that he has reached a breaking point, lashing out at senators who are blocking voting rights legislation.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s decision to call for changing the Senate’s rules to pass voting rights protections was a long time coming. Perhaps — in the view of his most disaffected supporters — too long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Reggie Wilson Explores the Power of Moving Together
description: The choreographer continues his research into African American worship and the Black Shakers in “Power” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music
content: Even the choreographer Reggie Wilson sees how many would think that his new piece, “Power,” is just another version of “ … they stood shaking while others began to shout,” which premiered in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Is Gruyère Still Gruyère if It Doesn’t Come From Gruyères?
description: A federal judge says yes, siding with U.S. cheese producers who say gruyère can be produced anywhere, not just in Switzerland and France.
content: In Europe, the mild, smooth and nutty cheese called gruyère must have a slightly damp texture, with average spring and low crumble. It must be in the shape of a wheel, weighing between 55 and 88 pounds. Fruity notes must dominate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: It Started With a Kiss. Then Film Scholars Found More.
description: MoMA’s series on film restorations, To Save and Project, is highlighting Black cinema, including what may be the earliest example of African American intimacy onscreen.
content: Even in the 19th century, a film could have an extended cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Republican Gerrymander of North Carolina Maps Is Upheld in Court
description: The ruling set up a final battle over the maps in the state Supreme Court, where Democrats hold a slim edge.
content: WASHINGTON — A North Carolina state court on Tuesday rejected claims by voting rights advocates that Republican gerrymanders of the state’s political maps were unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: Consumer prices popped again in December, casting a shadow over the economy.
description: The Consumer Price Index increased at the fastest pace in 40 years, a new report showed.
content: Inflation climbed to its highest level in 40 years at the end of 2021, a troubling development for President Biden and economic policymakers as rapid price gains erode consumer confidence and cast a shadow of uncertainty over the economy’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
description: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?
content: HAYNEVILLE, Ala. — What babbles behind Marilyn Rudolph’s house in the rural countryside is no brook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: The Visions of Penélope Cruz
description: She already felt a mystical connection with the director Pedro Almodóvar. For their seventh collaboration, “Parallel Mothers,” she gave her all, even collapsing after one scene.
content: You have to wonder if Penélope Cruz manifested her first phone call from Pedro Almodóvar. As a young girl growing up in Madrid, she watched Betamax tapes of his movies over and over, hoping that the Spanish auteur might find a place for her in his bright and bold world. She dreamed about it so often that the day he did phone her about a role, it didn’t even feel like the first call — it felt like the tenth, or the hundredth, from someone she already knew very well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What Putin Really Wants From the Ukraine Crisis
description: He wants to break NATO’s back. And he might succeed.
content: Grave may have been the mistakes of Donald Rumsfeld, but George W. Bush’s first defense secretary did have a gift for memorable phrases. One of them — “weakness is provocative” — explains the predicament we again find ourselves in with Russia’s belligerence against Ukraine and NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Ambition or Compromise?
description: After President Biden’s speech on voting rights, we explain the two camps in the debate about how to protect them.
content: President Biden and congressional Democrats are making a new push to pass a voting-rights bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir, Lola Fadulu and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: ‘My Last Time Seeing Them:’ Remembering Those Killed in Bronx Fire
description: The day after his 12th birthday, Muhammad Drammeh died along with his mother and two of his sisters.
content: Muhammad Drammeh’s 12th birthday was on Saturday. He celebrated with his brother and sisters at an indoor trampoline park in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dodge
title: Can Monitoring Brain Waves Boost Mental Health?
description: Neurofeedback has promised a mental health revolution for decades. But is it effective?
content: Twice a week, Stephanie, a 37-year-old artist based in Boston, meets with her therapist to work on improving symptoms associated with post-traumatic stress disorder, which include flashbacks, bad dreams and suicidal thoughts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Two Women, a Burglary and a Glitter Fight. Another Florida Mystery.
description: A confrontation at an apartment complex in Clearwater, Fla., led to burglary charges for two women who were armed with containers of glitter, the authorities said.
content: Two women have been charged with felony burglary, accused of breaking into a man’s apartment in Clearwater, Fla., and throwing containers of glitter at him during an argument, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Adams
title: Does Art Have to Be Relevant? One Prominent Critic Says No.
description: The composer John Adams reviews a new book by Jed Perl, “Authority and Freedom: A Defense of the Arts.”
content: AUTHORITY AND FREEDOMA Defense of the ArtsBy Jed Perl
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: The Army of Millions Who Enforce China’s Zero-Covid Policy, at All Costs
description: As the troubled lockdown in Xi’an has shown, many Chinese people remain willing to work diligently toward the government’s goal of eliminating the virus, no matter the consequences.
content: China’s “zero Covid” policy has a dedicated following: the millions of people who work diligently toward that goal, no matter the human costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How Much Should You Fret About Rising Federal Debt?
description: The federal government is borrowing cheaply, but its debt could reach a tipping point.
content: It’s hard to know how much to worry about the federal debt of the United States. Believers in Modern Monetary Theory, most of whom lean liberal, say deficits and debt aren’t a threat so long as they don’t cause the economy to exceed its speed limit. Republicans in Congress worry a lot about the debt now, but many of them were more tolerant of it when a fellow Republican occupied the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spanish doctors who lacked protective gear early in the pandemic win compensation.
description: The ruling was the first in a raft of suits brought by doctors and nurses in Spain who say they worked without masks, gowns or surgical gloves.
content: A court in Spain has ordered a regional government to compensate doctors who worked on the front line of the coronavirus pandemic without adequate protective gear like masks, gowns or surgical gloves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Omicron on Capitol Hill
description: The variant is taking an already charged atmosphere and turning the dial up to 11.
content: Omicron has ushered in a new and frustrating phase of the pandemic. Soft shutdowns, empty shelves and another pandemic winter spent at home have shortened tempers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: André Onana Just Wants to Play
description: Cameroon’s 25-year-old goalkeeper has already had his career interrupted twice by bans. Now he’s back, and eager to move on.
content: For a goalkeeper of Andre Onana’s experience, the passage of play midway through the first half of Cameroon’s Africa Cup of Nations opener should have been routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Joe Coscarelli
title: Ronnie Spector, Who Brought Edge to Girl-Group Sound, Dies at 78
description: As a member of the Ronettes, she sang on the hits “Be My Baby” and “Baby, I Love You.”
content: Ronnie Spector, the lead singer of the Ronettes, the 1960s vocal trio that gave a passionate, bad-girl edge to pop’s girl-group sound with hits like “Be My Baby” and “Baby, I Love You,” died on Wednesday. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Mockingbird,’ Once a Broadway Smash, to Pause Production Amid Omicron
description: “Girl From the North Country,” a musical using the songs of Bob Dylan, also closed, with hopes of reopening in the spring, as the surge in virus cases continues to upend the theater industry.
content: The producers of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” a hit play that had been packing in audiences before the pandemic, announced Wednesday that they would shut down the show until June, lay off the cast and crew, downsize the production and then reopen in a smaller theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Amazon Prime: Loved at Almost Any Price
description: For many Americans, it has become hard to imagine online shopping without Prime.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Elizabeth Holmes is set to be sentenced on Sept. 26.
description: Ms. Holmes, the Theranos founder, faces up to 20 years in prison for each of four counts that led to a conviction in her federal fraud trial.
content: Elizabeth Holmes, the Silicon Valley start-up founder convicted of fraud this month, will be sentenced on Sept. 26, according to a court filing on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen and Jeanna Smialek
title: Libor, Long the Most Important Number in Finance, Dies at 52
description: Bankers used it until the end. Regulators say good riddance after its infamous fall.
content: The London interbank offered rate, a number that spent decades as a central force of international finance and was used in setting interest rates on everything from mortgages to student loans, has died after a long battle with regulators. It was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Make Your Own Animated GIFs
description: You can easily transform photos and videos into GIF files to share with family, friends or the world at large.
content: Online “visual” reactions have come a long way since the first sideways smiley-face emoticon appeared four decades ago. Animated GIFs — those files showing a few seconds of choppy motion, like the one of Kermit the Frog flailing his arms excitedly — are ubiquitous in text messages, online forums and chat apps, thanks to the internet’s meme culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Her Members-Only Couples Network Is Also Group Therapy
description: When Toni-Ann Craft created Friends with Rings, a membership network for engaged and married couples, it was a lifeline for her own marriage.
content: In 2019, a year into their marriage, Toni-Ann Craft, 37, and Kenneth Craft Jr., 42, moved from their spacious two-bedroom condominium in Washington to a smaller, two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn, where Mrs. Craft grew up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Dear Mother’ Review: Mamarazzi
description: Laurent Lafitte directs and stars in this fast-paced French comedy about a man forced to reconnect with his mother.
content: In “Dear Mother,” Laurent Lafitte’s zippy feature directing debut, Jean-Louis (Lafitte) is on a mission to find the source of his existence — or “the origin of the world,” to borrow from the film’s French title, “L’Origine du Monde,” an explicit reference to the painting by the 19th-century artist Gustave Courbet of the, uh, female anatomy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Hughes and Sean Piccoli
title: Desperate Search for Those Missing in Bronx Fire: ‘We’re Still Waiting’
description: Two days after the fire, the city released a partial list of the deceased.
content: Worshipers at a mosque in the Bronx sat shoeless in small groups along the edge of the carpeted floor. Services were still almost an hour away, but as coffee containers arrived and cups were poured, the imam tried to comfort people caught between anguish and grief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Two Held in Fatal Shooting of the Memphis Rapper Young Dolph
description: One suspect was captured by federal marshals in Indiana after failing to surrender as he had promised on social media, the authorities said.
content: Two people have been arrested in the killing of the rapper Young Dolph, who was shot by two people while buying cookies at a bakery in Memphis in November, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Inflation, Beijing Olympics, Dry January: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How the Voting Rights Bills Miss the Target on Election Subversion
description: The proposed legislation and the push to reform the Electoral Count Act leave open a variety of pathways to subvert a presidential election.
content: More than a year after the attack on the Capitol, President Biden and congressional Democrats still seem nowhere close to enacting robust safeguards against another attempt to overturn a presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Woman Jailed in Iran Has Returned to U.K.
description: Aras Amiri, a arts worker employed by the British Council, was arrested in March 2018 on espionage charges. She was acquitted in August and flew back to Britain earlier this week.
content: LONDON — A British cultural organization said on Wednesday that one of its employees from Iran had been acquitted of espionage charges by that country’s Supreme Court and was back in Britain after spending more than three years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Miami-Bound Passenger Storms Cockpit in Honduras, Causing Flight Delay
description: As the American Airlines flight was boarding on Tuesday afternoon, the passenger entered the cockpit and “caused damage,” the airline said.
content: Of the thousands of cancellations and delays of airline flights in the past month, most have been caused by Covid-19 outbreaks or perilous weather. But a flight from Honduras to Miami on Tuesday was delayed for a more novel reason — a passenger stormed the cockpit and apparently tried to climb out a window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal, Austin Mitchell, Mooj Zadie, Jessica Cheung, Lynsea Garrison, M.J. Davis Lin, Chelsea Daniel and Marion Lozano
title: Russia and the U.S. Face Off Over Ukraine
description: Can Moscow be deterred from carrying out an invasion?
content: The diplomatic talks in Geneva this week are of a kind not seen in a long time: an effort to defuse the possibility of a major war in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Panel Seeks to Debunk Unfounded Theory About F.B.I. Role in Riot
description: The House select committee investigating the attack on the Capitol interviewed Ray Epps, a protester at the center of a right-wing conspiracy theory.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee examining the Jan. 6 attack disclosed on Tuesday that it had interviewed the man at the center of a right-wing conspiracy theory about who provoked the violence, noting that he had denied reports he urged protesters into the Capitol at the behest of federal law enforcement agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: 11 Macaroni and Cheese Recipes to Curl Up With on the Couch
description: When in doubt, coat noodles in cheese sauce and call it dinner.
content: All macaroni and cheese is good macaroni and cheese, but these recipes from New York Times Cooking are especially fine — and wide-ranging, whether saucy or creamy, tender or crispy, meat-studded or dairy-free. The picks below include some of the greatest interpretations, both classic and clever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: That Cloud of Smoke Is Not a Mirage
description: Cigarettes, once shunned, have made a comeback with a younger crowd who knows better.
content: On a recent not-so-wintry Thursday in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, when the only snowflakes seen were over text, a gang of 20-somethings stood in a circle outside Clearing Gallery, sharing a pack of American Spirits.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Mapped a Year of Extreme Weather
description: The Times analyzed temperature data from weather stations across the United States. The result: 2021 was a huge year for records, both high and low.
content: Temperatures in the United States last year set more heat and cold records than any other year since 1994, according to a New York Times analysis of weather station data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Don’t Sleep on These 6 Performances During Awards Season
description: As various nominating groups unveil their choices, these impressive turns have been largely overlooked. But there’s still time to rectify that, academy voters!
content: Now that the Screen Actors Guild has issued its nominations and the Golden Globes have … well, live-tweeted … this awards season’s acting races are starting to come into focus. Still, I’d like to coax adventurous Oscar voters to look elsewhere, since so many of the best performances were overlooked by both groups. Here are five stellar turns that still deserve their due, as well as a sixth performance that ought to be doing even better than it is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: The governor of West Virginia comes down with Covid-19.
description: Gov. Jim Justice developed symptoms and tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, and is receiving antibody treatment, his office said.
content: Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia has tested positive for the coronavirus and is feeling “extremely unwell,” his office announced on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Gerald Stern, a Founding New York Judicial Watchdog, Dies at 86
description: He was the first head of a state commission that investigated misconduct by judges and meted out discipline in nearly 600 cases during his 29-year tenure.
content: Gerald Stern, who for three decades set the bar for courtroom ethical standards in New York State as the first administrator of its Commission on Judicial Conduct, died on Jan. 6 in the Bronx. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Love, Trust and Heartbreak on Two Stages
description: The musical “Hadestown” and the opera “Eurydice” aim to offer new twists on a Greek myth. But when it comes to their heroine, they only go so far.
content: When Orpheus turned around to look at Eurydice during the closing performance of Matthew Aucoin and Sarah Ruhl’s “Eurydice” at the Metropolitan Opera, the audience’s collective gasp seemed to shake the grand theater. I recalled another time I heard such a gasp: from the character of Eurydice near the end of “Doubt Comes In,” a song in the Broadway musical “Hadestown.” Then, too, the audience gasped along with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margo Oge and Drew Kodjak
title: These Carbon-Spewing Vehicles Must Be Stopped
description: To meet his climate goals, President Biden must be more aggressive in ending new truck and bus emissions.
content: At a gathering on the White House lawn last August, President Biden spoke of a future in which electric cars and trucks will be the only vehicles on the road. “The question,” he said, “is whether we’ll lead or fall behind” in the global race to achieve that vision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Poised to Extend Health Care to All Undocumented Immigrants
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom unveiled a plan to allow people who are in the country illegally to sign up for Medi-Cal.
content: California has seen a sharp decline over the past decade in the number of residents who lack health insurance — with one major exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Isabella Kwai
title: ‘We must not allow this virus a free ride, or wave the white flag,’ the top W.H.O. official says.
description: Over the past week, a staggering average of 2.6 million new cases a day has been reported, according to according to the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University.
content: The World Health Organization admonished countries not to relax their guard against the coronavirus pandemic, just because the Omicron variant tends not to cause hospitalizations and deaths as often as earlier variants did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg, Lauren Hirsch and David McCabe
title: Why Some Workers Are Getting All the Covid Tests They Need
description: In the absence of a national effort to make coronavirus testing widely available, a number of big American companies ramped up their own, making tests available for a select group of workers.
content: The latest Covid-19 wave has left millions of Americans scrambling for tests, braving long lines in the cold at pop-up sites or searching furiously online for kits to use at home. But for a select group of employees at some of the country’s largest companies, tests are free and often readily available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘American Urbanist,’ a Well-Timed Biography of a Man Who Reshaped City Life
description: Richard K. Rein’s book tells the story of William H. Whyte, a sociologist who wrote “The Organization Man” and helped to rethink how cities look and feel.
content: Before crowdsourcing, there was groupthink. The first sounds almost jolly: a mosh pit of ideas. The second, a term introduced with sinister Orwellian overtones by William H. Whyte in a 1952 article for Fortune magazine, describes how creativity and even morality can be stifled by consensus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By B.D. McClay
title: What Is Miss America, if Not a Beauty Pageant?
description: Maybe the contest should coldly, openly reward women for being beautiful. Give them money. Don’t pretend that this is about what you can earn through hard work alone.
content: The Miss America Competition, which celebrated its 100th birthday this year, has now outlived key parties and manned missions to the moon, the VHS tape and the subway token, the Soviet Union and nitrate film. It outlives even itself, seeming to hang on more because the infrastructure remains in place than from anyone’s active desire to see it. And as last month’s streaming-only broadcast of the centennial pageant indicates, even inertia can get you only so far. People once watched Miss America on broadcast television, tens of millions of them; it was an institution of enough consequence to be worth protesting, as many did. But who needs a pageant these days? If you want to watch women strain to meet an ideal of femininity no person actually desires, you watch “The Bachelor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Orringer
title: A Memoir of a Young Girl’s Survival Amid Mounting Horrors
description: In “Mala’s Cat,” Mala Kacenberg describes her time hiding out in the forest during World War II after losing her family.
content: MALA’S CATA Memoir of Survival in World War IIBy Mala Kacenberg
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: More countries shift to self-administered antigen tests in a race to stop Omicron.
description: Countries aim keep up with the variant’s rapid pace of transmission, marking a shift from viewing P.C.R. testing as the primary method of diagnosis.
content: Rapid antigen testing kits have flooded into supermarkets, online shops and pharmacies around the world as countries race to keep up with the Omicron variant’s swift pace of transmission, marking a shift to the self-administered tests from P.C.R. testing, which has long been considered the gold standard for detecting the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Keith Bradsher
title: Omicron Deepens Uncertainty Surrounding Beijing Olympics
description: With the opening of the Winter Games three weeks away, officials in China are on high alert amid coronavirus outbreaks around the country.
content: The Winter Olympics are three weeks away, but tickets have yet to go on sale. Airlines are shifting schedules, creating travel confusion. Now, a spate of coronavirus outbreaks around China — including some locally transmitted cases of the fast-spreading Omicron variant — is adding to the uncertainty ahead of the Games in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Fritzsche
title: How Germans Reconciled Themselves to Defeat After World War II
description: Harald Jähner’s “Aftermath” recounts the complications of living in a battered country of rubble and ashes.
content: AFTERMATHLife in the Fallout of the Third Reich, 1945-1955By Harald Jähner
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Britain: A Restored Farm Compound on Cornwall’s Coast
description: In the bucolic southwestern county of Cornwall, demand is soaring as Britons ‘re-evaluate their lifestyles’ amid the pandemic.
content: This seven-bedroom property is in the historic village of St. Mawes, on the south shore of Cornwall county, in southwest England. The compound, a collection of converted farm buildings clustered around a gated courtyard, comprises a five-bedroom main residence, a two-bedroom cottage, a two-car garage with an upper-level studio space, and a garage/workshop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Fire in a High-rise? In Most Cases, the Fire Dept. Says Stay Put.
description: As relatives waited for victims of a deadly Bronx high-rise fire to be identified, officials said simple safety measures could make a difference.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at what fire officials and experts say is the best strategy if there is a fire in a high-rise building. We’ll also take a last ride on a subway stalwart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: 7 Ways to Remember Martin Luther King in New York
description: From in-person and virtual performances to exhibitions and tours, the city offers plenty of options for honoring the civil rights leader this year.
content: Since 1983, just 15 years after his death, the third Monday in January has been designated as a federal holiday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday. This year, on Jan. 17, cultural institutions all over New York have planned concerts, exhibitions, service opportunities and tours, both in person and online. (Bring your vaccination card, and check mask-wearing and ticketing policies online beforehand.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: After a ‘horrendous’ 2021, the I.R.S. will start the tax season with a major backlog.
description: At least 10 million returns from last year remain unprocessed because of short-staffing at the tax collector, according to the national taxpayer advocate.
content: The Internal Revenue Service will kick off the approaching tax season with a backlog of at least 10 million unprocessed returns from last year, according to a new report by the national taxpayer advocate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Biden-Cheney 2024?
description: Saving American democracy may involve following Israel’s example.
content: As I’ve noted before, one reason I pay very close attention to the Israeli-Palestinian arena is that a lot of trends get perfected there first and then go global — airline hijacking, suicide bombing, building a wall, the challenges of pluralism and lots more. It’s Off Broadway to Broadway, so what’s playing there these days that might be a harbinger for politics in the U.S.?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Maria Ewing, Dramatically Daring Opera Star, Dies at 71
description: She sought to incorporate acting techniques in her singing rather than settle for predictable staging. Uncertainty about her heritage inspired her daughter, the actress Rebecca Hall, to make the film “Passing.”
content: Maria Ewing, who sang notable soprano and mezzo-soprano roles at leading houses, including the Metropolitan Opera, beginning in the mid-1970s and whose ambiguity about her racial heritage helped drive her daughter, the actress and director Rebecca Hall, to make the recent movie “Passing,” died on Sunday at her home near Detroit. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Andreatta
title: Death of High School Hockey Player Renews Debate on Neck Guards
description: Canada and Sweden mandate neck protection for amateurs, but U.S.A. Hockey only recommends players wear neck guards. Teddy Balkind’s death could change that.
content: Expressions of grief after the death of Teddy Balkind, a high school hockey player in Connecticut, have spanned the ice hockey world, from pregame moments of silence in New England to tributes on “Hockey Night in Canada” broadcasts to hockey sticks set tenderly on porches from Manitoba to Minnesota to Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Netscape Founder Gives Up $35 Million in Art Said to Be Stolen
description: “Why would you want to own something that was stolen?” said James H. Clark, who investigators said had been persuaded to buy dozens of looted items by a rogue dealer.
content: Over a period of five years, James H. Clark, the internet pioneer whose Netscape browser once commanded that market, spent roughly $35 million, he recalled in an interview, to purchase dozens of Cambodian and Southeast Asian antiquities, many of which he used to furnish a penthouse in Miami Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weapon Burger
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Lemon Pepper Makes Everything Better — Especially Wings
description: Zesty, buttery lemon-pepper wings are Atlanta’s soul. But you can use the seasoning on just about anything.
content: On July 30, 2020, the Los Angeles Clippers lost to the Lakers, 103-101. Some have suggested this defeat had to do with the absence of the Clippers guard Lou Williams, who broke the N.B.A.’s Covid protocol in order to stop by Magic City, a strip club in downtown Atlanta. Williams, an Atlanta native, was in town to attend a memorial service but had to quarantine for 10 days after being caught inside the gentlemen’s club. He missed a couple of games. A P.R. maelstrom ensued, and Williams was called “Lemon Pepper Lou” — a nickname he has since trademarked — because, he said, he was hitting the club for its lemon-pepper chicken wings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Disgusts You?
description: What smells, tastes, textures or ideas make you say “ick”?
content: How do you feel when you look at the image of moldy fruit at the top of this post? Are you disgusted?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Health Workers: How Are You Coping With Omicron?
description: As hospitals once again fill up with coronavirus patients, we’d love to know how you’re doing.
content: Two years into the pandemic, as Omicron sends cases soaring, more health care workers are at the breaking point. One in five health care workers left the field during the pandemic, and those who remain talk about an excess of stress, a lack of fair compensation, and a dearth of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Sorry, World: Famous Apologies by High-Profile Figures
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s self-abasing apology, for attending a party during a pandemic lockdown, joins a long list of mea culpas by the prominent and powerful.
content: Some of the I’m Sorries are too little, too late, others are greeted sympathetically. Some are for transgressions that festered into scandal, others for spectacular errors of judgment or worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Supply chain snags continued to drive up prices in December.
description: The surge in coronavirus cases is idling workers at ports and trucking companies, while strong consumer demand continues to drive up the cost of shipping and energy.
content: Persistent challenges in getting goods from factories to customers continue to drive up the price of cars, computer chips, furniture and other products, pushing up consumer prices in December at the fastest rate since 1982.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Gender Gap Is Taking Us to Unexpected Places
description: With unforeseen and underexplored consequences.
content: In one of the most revealing studies in recent years, a 2016 survey of 137,456 full-time, first-year students at 184 colleges and universities in the United States, the U.C.L.A. Higher Education Research Institute found “the largest-ever gender gap in terms of political leanings: 41.1 percent of women, an all-time high, identified themselves as liberal or far left, compared to 28.9 percent of men.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: I See Signs of Despair From Parents of Kids Under 5
description: Disrupted daycare, vaccines TBD and bosses who are over Covid excuses.
content: I’ve been talking to parents about pandemic stress for nearly two years, and I haven’t heard the level of despair that I’ve heard over the past week since the spring of 2020. Some of the words parents used to describe their January 2022: “devastating,” “disgusting” and “at a breaking point.” The difference with the Omicron surge is that the upset is more concentrated among parents of children under the age of 5.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russia Professes ‘No Intention to Invade.’ Ukraine Isn’t Convinced.
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 12, 2022.
content: “When Russians say, ‘No, no, no, we don’t want to invade Ukraine,’ what they mean is, ‘Yes, yes, yes, we do want to invade Ukraine.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Beijing’s Olympic Challenge
description: Can “zero-Covid” last with thousands of visitors?
content: The Winter Olympics are just three weeks away, but tickets have yet to go on sale. Airlines are shifting schedules, creating travel confusion. Now, there is a spate of Covid outbreaks in China, including some cases of the fast-spreading Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Newest Corporate Perk
description: Need a Covid rapid test? One solution is to work for the right big company.
content: As the Omicron variant of the coronavirus surges across the country, tests are in short supply. But for a select group of employees at corporate America’s largest firms, tests are free and often readily available. These companies have been buying tests in bulk, some as part of their return-to-office protocols and others as a perk to offer workers peace of mind — even for those not yet coming into the office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Jones
title: The Joys (and Challenges) of Sex After 70
description: Sex can drop off in our final decades. But for those who keep going, it can be the best of their lives.
content: Before David and Anne married, they hadn’t ventured beyond touching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Jonny Greenwood: First Radiohead, Now Orchestras and Film
description: Scoring films like “The Power of the Dog” and “Spencer,” he has become a major composer, his concert music fueling his soundtracks.
content: Jonny Greenwood had long since achieved global fame, as the lead guitarist of Radiohead, when he ventured into scoring films nearly 20 years ago. To some, this seemed at first like a side hustle, something to keep Greenwood occupied between albums and tours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: A Voting Rights Push, as States Make Voting Harder
description: President Biden says he won’t keep “quiet” any longer about protecting ballot access. But voting rights groups say he should’ve raised his voice months ago.
content: In the nine months since Republicans in Georgia muscled through a host of new voting restrictions, 18 other states have enacted 33 such laws. More than 30 states have concluded their redistricting processes, with extreme partisan gerrymandering locking in Republican control over legislatures in the electoral battlegrounds of Georgia, North Carolina, Ohio and Texas for another 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Epstein Accuser’s Lawsuit Against Prince Andrew Can Proceed, Judge Rules
description: Virginia Giuffre has sued Andrew, the second son of Queen Elizabeth II, accusing him of raping her when she was a teenager.
content: A lawsuit against Prince Andrew brought by Virginia Giuffre, a woman who claimed he raped her when she was a teenager, will be allowed to proceed after a federal judge in Manhattan denied Andrew’s request to dismiss the suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Covid-19 was the leading cause of death among U.S. police officers in 2021, a report says.
description: Nearly 460 officers died in the line of duty in 2021, making it the deadliest in more than 90 years. Some officers and police unions continue to push back against vaccine mandates.
content: For the second year in a row, Covid-19 was the leading cause of death for law enforcement officers in the United States, according to a report released on Tuesday by the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Grid, a ‘Fuller Picture’ News Site, Goes Live
description: The latest media start-up, with millions in funding and a team of more than 20 journalists, aims to bring clarity to weighty issues.
content: Grid, a news site more than a year in the making, went live early Wednesday, with the goal of becoming a one-stop media shop for detailed renderings of the biggest stories of the day and why they matter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2021 in Jazz: Intimacy and Conversation
description: Throughout the pandemic, the music’s flexibility has become an asset. Where will artists take it next?
content: Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, jazz’s flexibility has become an asset. It informed how 2021 played out in the jazz world — the return of Pharoah Sanders with a new, unlikely collaborator, the electronic musician Floating Points; interesting intersections with hip-hop that call back to earlier jazz fusion; duet recordings that emphasize call and response, two artists communicating across the empty transom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Lael Brainard will call inflation ‘too high’ at nomination hearing for Fed vice chair.
description: Ms. Brainard, a Federal Reserve governor whom President Biden nominated for vice chair, will say the central bank is focused on getting price gains back down.
content: Lael Brainard, a Federal Reserve governor whom President Biden has nominated to be the central bank’s new vice chair, plans to tell lawmakers that the central bank will use its policies to wrestle inflation under control when she testifies at her confirmation hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: The South End of Stamford, Conn.: Master-Planned With Luxury Rentals, and Lots of Pets
description: The neighborhood, a 322-acre peninsula on Long Island Sound, has been redeveloped with 4,000 new apartments. And there are more to come.
content: Over the past 13 years, the South End of Stamford, Conn., a 322-acre peninsula on Long Island Sound, has gained more than 4,000 new rental apartments, most in fancy high-rises. Part of a master-planned, mixed-use development called Harbor Point, the apartments have helped inject new energy into an area formerly pocked with decaying industrial sites and brownfields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: The Weddings Section Asks What It Means to Be Committed in 2022
description: The Times Weddings editor Charanna Alexander discusses the decision to move away from the traditional Times wedding announcement and her plans for the section.
content: In 1851, the debut issue of The New York Times, then known as The New-York Daily Times, announced the marriage of John Grant and Sarah Mullett, who was from a prominent family in Fredonia, N.Y. At the time, high society marriages were cultural and social news. The tradition of reporting on the nuptials of the elite evolved into The Times Weddings section.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Intelligent Life’ Review: Cecily Strong’s ‘Awerobics’ Workout
description: Taking Lily Tomlin’s roles in a revival of Jane Wagner’s metaphysical comedy, the “Saturday Night Live” star is put through her paces.
content: Of the many lines that have stuck with me since I saw the original Broadway production of “The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe” in 1985, perhaps the sharpest was the one that seemed aimed directly at my generation of disappointed go-getters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Chicago Schools Reopen After a Stalemate
description: Schools across the U.S. also struggle with Covid tests. Plus, a genius teacher tip for resolving conflicts.
content: Today, Chicago classrooms reopen as Los Angeles and other districts struggle to test students for the coronavirus. And a federal lawsuit accuses 16 top private colleges and universities of price-fixing on financial aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson, Under Fire, Apologizes for Pandemic Party
description: The British prime minister, on the defensive after a series of ethical lapses, said, “There were things we simply did not get right” about a gathering at Downing Street during a lockdown in 2020.
content: LONDON — Facing a potentially lethal threat to his leadership, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Wednesday offered a contrite apology for attending a Downing Street garden party while his country was under a strict coronavirus lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What We’re Looking Forward to This Year
description: Hopes and goals for 2022.
content: Welcome. On the last day of last year, I asked what, if anything, you were looking forward to in 2022. Since then, I’ve been thinking of Anne Shirley’s optimistic query in “Anne of Green Gables”: “Marilla, isn’t it nice to think that tomorrow is a new day with no mistakes in it yet?” When I read the Anne books as a child, I found this simple insight comforting, each new day laid out like a clean sheet of loose-leaf paper, all potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: This month’s picks include a personal essay on tobacco, an experimental look at pieces of the Berlin Wall and a chronicle of a revolt in Wukan, China.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Kevin McCarthy Refuses Interview Request From Jan. 6 Committee
description: The panel said it was interested in conversations the top House Republican had with President Donald J. Trump on the day of the riot and afterward.
content: WASHINGTON — The House select committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Wednesday formally requested an interview with Representative Kevin McCarthy, taking the unusual step of calling the minority leader, who was in close contact with former President Donald J. Trump before, during and after the violence and has fought to shut down any investigation of the events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Texas Man Is First Charged Under New Antidoping Law in U.S.
description: The law targets people who would skirt doping regulations in international competitions, but it does not apply to major American leagues like the N.F.L. and Major League Baseball.
content: A man in Texas on Wednesday became the first person charged under a new federal law that makes it a crime to enable doping in international sports competitions. The man, Eric Lira, described by prosecutors as a “naturopathic therapist,” is accused of providing performance-enhancing drugs to at least two athletes, including at least one sprinter who used them to bolster her performance at the Tokyo Olympics last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: Eric Adams Cuts His Brother’s Duties After Giving Him Top Police Job
description: Amid concerns of nepotism, Bernard Adams will be executive director of mayoral security, not deputy police commissioner. He will earn $210,000.
content: When Mayor Eric Adams named a Virginia parking administrator and retired police sergeant to a top position in the New York Police Department, he said the man had one qualification that no one else there possessed: He was the mayor’s brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Housing costs swell, hampering home buyers and pushing up rents.
description: Rent costs, a key component of inflation, surged 0.4 percent in December, putting pressure on the Federal Reserve to tamp down rising prices.
content: Housing costs jumped last month, as higher prices continued to constrain aspiring home buyers and push up the demand for apartment and home leases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Used to Run Several Times a Week. Now He Could Barely Stand.
description: Could an unusual drug habit account for such a rapid decline?
content: The mother stood in the baggage-claim area of the Buffalo Niagara International Airport, waiting for her 37-year-old son, who had just flown in from North Carolina. The carousel was nearly empty by the time she caught sight of him. She was shocked by how sick he looked. His face was pale and thin, his hair and clothes rumpled as if he felt too awful to care. Most surprising of all: He was being rolled toward her in a wheelchair. “I had some trouble with the stairs,” he explained. He thanked the attendant and then struggled to get to his feet. He didn’t make it. Before he got more than a few inches off the seat, his arms and then his legs began to shake and wobble, and he fell heavily back into the chair. His mother collected his bag and pushed him out to where her husband was waiting in the car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Anton Troianovski
title: NATO and Russia Talk Frankly, but Past One Another for Now
description: Four hours of frank and serious discussion between Russia and the 30-member alliance leave unanswered whether Vladimir V. Putin will choose diplomacy or war.
content: BRUSSELS — After four hours of talks with Russia, NATO leaders said that they were willing to engage in serious diplomacy with Moscow over arms control and missile deployments in Europe, but they rejected outright Russian demands that the alliance stop enlargement, pull back its forces from member states bordering Russia and guarantee that Ukraine will never join.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Criticized by Senators, U.S. Health Officials Defend Omicron Response
description: Lawmakers accused top Biden administration health officials of neglecting virus testing and mangling key messaging around the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — Top federal health officials on Tuesday defended the Biden administration’s efforts to protect Americans from the highly contagious Omicron variant, facing withering accusations from senators about the scarcity of coronavirus tests and confusing guidance on how soon people who test positive for the virus can return to normal life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Perfect Season Eludes Every Men’s Team, Again
description: Baylor and U.S.C. lost, assuring that Indiana in 1975-76 will remain the last undefeated champion for another season.
content: Scott May, Kent Benson, Quinn Buckner, Bob Knight and the Indiana team of 1975-76 can rest easy. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: A Wet January, Thanks to Covid
description: Not drinking for a month sounded easy enough. But for some, Omicron changed those plans.
content: Ashley Deringer had her sights set on a Dry January this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gage Daughdrill
title: Five Minimalist Workout-Wear Brands to Know
description: To help ease you into the new year, and perhaps a new exercise routine, a roundup of lines offering clothes both functional and fashion-forward.
content: When the London-based creative director Anna Laub founded Prism over a decade ago, the brand’s product offering consisted solely of streamlined modern eyewear, but it has since evolved to encompass resort and swimwear — and, in 2019, activewear, under the diffusion line Prism Squared. This most recent venture began with a mission to find a fabric that would give garments not only a comfortable fit but also an opaque finish, a process that eventually led to a signature knit that she now uses for all of the line’s pieces, from seamless ribbed sports bras to elegant long-sleeve leotards. The textile, created from a blend of strong but elastic fibers, is both quick-drying and chlorine-resistant, making it uniquely versatile. “Everything is designed to be used as swimwear, sportswear, underwear or shapewear,” Laub says. “The fabric allows for powerful fits that provide support without a traditional under-wiring structure.” Sustainability is also at the forefront of her vision: Each collection is made in Italy using 3-D knitting techniques that create less waste. Furthermore, clothes that serve multiple purposes, says Laub, encourage shoppers to “buy better and buy less.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Charleroy
title: Exploring the Creative Process With ‘Live Art’
description: In this art lesson, we invite students to watch illustrators draw and discuss the choices they make in their work. Then, students experiment with these practices in their own projects.
content: Featured Series: Live Art
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Alan Scott, Doctor Behind the Medical Use of Botox, Dies at 89
description: An ophthalmologist and researcher, he discovered a drug that treated serious eye conditions. It also smoothed wrinkles — and an alternative industry was born.
content: It is a neurotoxin 100 times more deadly than cyanide and the cause of the food-borne illness known as botulism. During World War II and for some years after, the Department of Defense hoped to develop it as a chemical weapon. But it wasn’t until the 1970s that Alan Scott, an ophthalmologist, turned this toxin, Clostridium botulinum, into a pharmaceutical, when he began to investigate it as a medical treatment for serious eye impairments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Food Carts, Bravery and Vocabulary Stories
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to explore the world of New York City’s food carts, share about a time when they were brave, participate in a vocabulary-based storytelling challenge, write an image-inspired story and watch a film about grieving pre-Covid days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: SAG Award Nominations 2022: The Complete List, Snubs and Surprises
description: “Being the Ricardos” hit big, but some likely contenders, including Kristen Stewart, were overlooked.
content: With the Golden Globes reduced to a chaotic session of live-tweeting, let’s hope this year’s Screen Actors Guild Awards can finally bring a little clarity to Oscar season. Indeed, the SAG Awards, voted on by the Hollywood actors’ guild SAG-AFTRA, are considered by many to be the strongest precursor when it comes to predicting Oscar momentum in the acting races: In most years, at least four of the five SAG nominees in each acting category will also receive an Oscar nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: ‘Genevieve Is Pitching Because She Can Get Outs’
description: At 17, Genevieve Beacom became the first woman to play for one of Australia’s top professional baseball teams. She hopes her next stop is college ball in the United States.
content: One of the few times Genevieve Beacom can remember boys or men objecting to her playing baseball among them came when she was 11. She was a star pitcher, even at that age, and a boy on another team was so adamant about not facing her that he began to cry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Seal, Chris Libbey and Nick Libbey
title: The Landlord’s Worst Nightmare Is a Basic Human Right
description: The comedian and journalist Jeff Seal takes to the streets to rally support for a little-known bill that would protect millions of New Yorkers from unjust evictions. But a powerful lobby stands in its way.
content: New Yorkers pay some of the highest rents in the nation — and are among the most vulnerable to being evicted with little notice. For years, the city’s real estate industry has spent a fortune exerting its influence in the State Capitol, leaving tenants largely at its mercy. Meanwhile the cost of living continues to rise and the number of rent-regulated apartments continues to dwindle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Cause for an ‘Aha!’
description: Adam Aaronson is counting on you.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Adam Aaronson’s ninth New York Times Crossword puzzle certainly elicits an “aha!” — the theme is a bit of a thinker and may not click until after the solve. For me, this makes the puzzle that much more satisfying; I love the feeling of a theme falling into place at the revealer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: How Candy Leads to Deforestation
description: In 2010, some of the world’s biggest companies said they would eliminate deforestation from their supply chains by 2020. Did it happen?

title: White House Pledges Millions of Free Virus Tests to Schools
description: The Biden administration said it would provide millions of rapid antigen and lab-based coronavirus tests to the nation’s K-12 schools each month in an effort keep them open amid spread of the Omicron variant.

title: Corrections: Jan. 12, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 12, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about China’s latest pandemic lockdown strategy referred incorrectly to the university that Zhang Shengzi attends. It is a university in Xi’an, not the University of Xi’an.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: It’s just the right time for turkey chili and biscuits, and quick-braised chicken with greens.
content: Good morning. Everyone holding up where you stay? These are some tricky times! It’s important to remember that your good day may be a bad one for someone else. Your best bet, as ever, is empathy and a bias toward good will. My friend Julia has been cooking madly for others stuck in quarantine, leaving deli containers full of soup and stew at the doors of her neighbors. She’s spreading cheer where cheer is in short supply. I hope we can all follow her example this week: three-sisters stew, maybe, or lemony carrot and cauliflower soup.
source.name: The New York Times
